sn35.79:1.1: Then a monk went up to the Buddha …
sn35.79:1.3: “Sir, is there one thing such that by giving it up a monk gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge?”
sn35.79:4.1: “Ignorance is one thing such that by giving it up a monk gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge.”
sn35.79:5.1: “But how does a monk know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”
sn35.79:6.1: “When a monk knows and sees the seer, the seen, eye consciousness, and eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
sn35.79:6.2: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises. …
sn35.79:6.3: Knowing and seeing the thinker, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
sn35.79:6.4: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
sn35.79:6.5: That’s how a monk knows and sees so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”
